title: 108_s2511
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004". It includes definitions for the Chimayo Water Supply System. The Act, known as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004", defines key terms such as Secretary, study area, system, and town. It mandates a feasibility study by the Secretary to construct a water supply system for the town of Chimayo in the Santa Cruz River Valley, including transmission lines, pump stations, and reservoirs. The Secretary is mandated to conduct a feasibility study for a water supply system in Chimayo, considering various water sources and total lifecycle costs. The Secretary is required to determine the total lifecycle costs of the water supply system in Chimayo, including operation, maintenance, and management costs. The study must be completed within 3 years, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. Coordination with relevant agencies is necessary for accessing land and drilling exploratory wells. The Secretary will conduct a feasibility study on water resources in Chimayo within 3 years, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. Emergency water supply development assistance contracts may be entered into with water authorities in the study area for activities like hauling water. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of completion or 4 years after enactment of the Act. The Secretary may provide assistance for various water-related activities, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. Eligible activities include hauling water, installing water purification technology, drilling wells, and more as determined appropriate by the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations for sections 102 and 103 is set at $2,000,000 for fiscal years 2005 through 2008 and $3,000,000 for fiscal years 2005 through 2010. Funds under section 102 cannot be used for water infrastructure construction. The Secretary will provide financial assistance for the construction of the Espanola water filtration facility in New Mexico, including projects for diverting and using imported water, such as presedimentation basins and an influent pump station. The construction of presedimentation basins, influent pump station, pretreatment facility, filtration facilities, finished water storage facilities, finished water booster pump station, sludge dewatering facilities, and potable water transmission lines in Espanola, New Mexico. Financial assistance may be provided for water delivery infrastructure development for Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos and non-Federal sponsors. Reclaimed water will be used to enhance groundwater and surface water supplies. Federal sponsors will cover up to 25 percent of the total cost for water delivery infrastructure development for Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos. Funds from the Secretary cannot be used for operation or maintenance of the facility. Authorization of $3,000,000 for facility construction from 2005 to 2009.
